Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Precision Control of Nanopositioners

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) research project between the University of Utah (UU), Villanova University (VU), and industry partner Molecular Vista, Inc. (MVI) is to study new design and control system approaches for the development of advanced nanopositioning systems for nanoscale science and engineering applications. Specifically, the research outcomes will lead to improvement in the performance of nanotechnologies, such as video-rate scanning probe microscopy, desktop nano-rapid prototyping and nanomanufacturing systems, precision advanced additive manufacturing systems, and micro rapid inspection and repair systems. The research collaboration and the proposed education plan will expose engineering students (graduate and undergraduate), K-12 students, and the community to cutting-edge research and findings in control, nanotechnology, and high-impact industry applications. Additionally, students involved in the research will be encouraged to pursue graduate studies and industry positions in control and nano-scale science and engineering.

The scope of this research is to study new design and control paradigms for dual-stage nanopositioners that consider both spatial and temporal constraints. Emerging dual-stage nanopositioners have the unique ability to achieve long-range and high-speed operation, as well as operating bandwidths two- to three-orders of magnitude higher than existing systems. However, typical control strategies rely on temporal (frequency-based) information to split the control effort between the two actuators, which results in some precision positioning trajectories being unachievable. Specifically, low-speed trajectories are assumed to be long-range and diverted to the long-range, low-speed actuator while high-speed trajectories are assumed to be short-range and diverted to the short-range, high speed actuator. Thus, short-range, low-speed inputs are diverted to the long-range, low-speed actuator, which can be problematic since the long-range actuator has a lower positioning resolution than the short-range, high-speed actuator, which is better suited to track the short-range trajectory (regardless of speed). Therefore, dual-stage nanopositioners cannot achieve high positioning resolution when range and frequency are not inversely correlated. To advance the state-of-the-art, a control-centered design approach is planned to establish the guidelines and requirements for creating high-performance dual-stage nanopositioners. To enhance the understanding and control system design process, detailed input-output models that capture the dynamics of the system (nonlinear and dynamic effects) and sensor characteristics will be obtained. An innovative control algorithm which systematically considers both spatial and temporal information will be developed to effectively allocate the control input. Finally, with support from the industry partner, the research team will evaluate the technology on a commercial atomic force microscope (AFM) system and consider future commercialization opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between researchers and experts at the University of Utah, Villanova University, and Molecular Vista, Inc.  The goal was to study new design and control methods for dual-stage nanopositioners that consider both spatial and temporal constraints. The main objectives focused on control-centered mechanical design, system modeling, and spatial-temporal control system design.  While the project focused on the development of high-speed, long-range, high-precision and high-accuracy dual-stage nanopositioning systems, the research outcomes can be applied to a broad range of dual-stage systems such as hard disk drive mechanisms, high-precision machining and advanced manufacturing systems, additive manufacturing systems, macro-scale robotic manipulators, or any other systems where high-precision, high-accuracy positioning is required over a long-range.

The key research outcomes include:

(1) Control-centered mechanical design methodologies for multi-axis dual-stage systems that leveraged detailed system models (including relevant nonlinearities). The development of nanopositioning stages included the development of a novel three-axis dual-stage positioning system and a novel omni-direction slip-stick microrobotic positioning stage. This work resulted in 1 journal and 2 conference papers and was used experimentally in 2 journal papers and 1 conference paper. It also resulted in 1 book chapter and 1 poster presentation.

(2) Novel control approaches for dual-stage systems that accounted for spatial and temporal constraints. The development of control approaches that consider both spatial (range) and temporal (frequency) aspects of the signals had two different thrusts. First, methods that focused on trajectory design for the individual actuators (which included both online and offline implementations). Second, methods that used feedback control. This work resulted in 3 journal publications, 6 conference publications, 1 poster, and 1 workshop presentation.

(3) The development of a prototype dual-stage system that was integrated into a commercial scanning probe microscope system for experimental validation. The stage described in (1) was integrated with a commercial atomic force microscope (AFM) system provided by industry partner Molecular Vista, Inc.  The system was used to validate the controllers designed in (2). This work was presented in 2 journal papers and 2 conference papers.

In total, the research team produced 8 conference papers, 4 journal publications, 2 poster presentations, 1 book chapter, and one workshop presentation. The work was also disseminated through conference and invited presentations.

Beyond the technical achievements, this project involved 5 graduate students (3 from Utah and 2 from Villanova) and 3 undergraduate students (2 from Utah and 1 from Villanova).  Students at all levels received training in mechanical design, compliant mechanisms, control engineering, precision mechatronics, robotics, algorithm development and implementation, and data analysis.  The students involved also co-authored technical publications that were presented at professional meetings and published archival journals. This resulted in advancement of the technical writing and presentation and oral communication skills. In addition, students from Villanova and Utah were encouraged to work together, expanding their professional networks and learning how to work remotely with colleagues.
